_header: Now hath ye heard both old and young
Note: For other MSS without a prologue, see 3245; for others with a 16-line Prologue, see 3122.
_description: Prognostics from the day on which Christmas falls, with a 32-line prologue — in couplets.

BodDig88.First Lines:
Now hathe ye harde bothe olde & yongeDiscriuede many a dyuers
                    thyng…
BodDig88.Last Lines:
…What woman that day of childe travaileThey shall bothe be in
                    grete paraile amen
BodDig88.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 63-7.

BLHar1735.First Lines:
NOw haue þe herd boþn held & yungDyscryeyed many
                    dyuers thing…
BLHar1735.Last Lines:
…Leue vs so to don quat so be falleÞat we to hys blys mon
                    come alle
BLHar1735.Note:
The first transcription includes the Prologue, 32 lines; the second is
                    the text 120 lines; formerly listed under 3122. Folio number reflects the most recent
                    foliation.

             “Practical Didactic Works in Middle English.”
